title: Between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020, will an armed group from Sudan engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Sudan?
preds:
I am surprised by the resiliency of the opposition to military rule. I thought Sudanese would have buckled by now.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/jun/30/fears-of-violence-as-sudan-gets-ready-for-million-man-march-khartoum
approx 61 killed by military since june
already has, ignoring the non recognised N and S

Let’s see what happens with this...but considering the challenges in Ethiopia, not sure if this will happen. More concerned about increasing influence of Janjaweed militias and their leader.
From the Economist:
“Leaders of the Sudanese Professionals’ Association, which has led the country’s protest movements, backed an Ethiopian roadmap to a transition to civilian government. It envisions a leadership council of eight protest leaders and seven military ones. Protests prompted the army to remove Omar al-Bashir as president in February, but continued as the generals showed no intention of giving up power.“
Seems the temper of the location and conflict

Difficult to tell with such little info coming out. The military acknowledges abuses and those responsible will be punished (just words at this point). Very little info coming out beyond capital (Khartoum), however. It sounds like both sides attempting to ratchet down (arresting military officers related to abuses and talks with government) but remains something of powderkeg?
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/jun/14/sudan-military-admits-abuses-committed-in-khartoum-attack
https://www.bbc.com/news/av/world-africa-48642546/sudan-protest-witnesses-saw-death-in-all-its-forms

I underestimated the current regime’s approach as I did the protestor’s resolve. Not a sure thing but going up substantially to 25%. From the Economist:
“The Nile’s two main tributaries, the Blue and White Nile, converge in Khartoum. But the forces on the ground in the Sudanese capital are pulling ever further apart. Anger remains high after more than 100 non-violent protesters demanding civilian rule were killed by the junta a week ago. A strike has shut down the city indefinitely. Most roads are empty. In almost every alley protesters have erected barricades and dug trenches to obstruct security forces. But some senior political leaders have been arrested. There are reports of pillage, gunfire and rape. Airport workers have been hauled from their homes and forced to work. The military council, which in April replaced Omar al-Bashir, the long-standing dictator, says it wants to reopen transition talks. But the forces behind the killing remain on the streets and many suspect they simply want to keep power. Without common ground, Sudan is set to slide further into chaos.“
Regime crackdown on protestors on the horizon. May get bloody.

Still saying question won’t be satisfied. Opposition not well organized and likely to cave
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/jun/03/sudan-khartoum-protest-gunfire-explosions-heard

In April, the military coup overthrew the Sudanese President Omar Al Bashir, who ruled the country for thirty years. Many people have been killed including soldiers. Also, the campaigns that systematically kill civilians could actually be policies or strategies such as reducing health care supplies, which can result in massive death.  http://time.com/5570009/sudan-activists-killed/

It appears that until Bashir is out of power civilians will continue to killed by their government. 
https://phr.org/resources/intimidation-and-persecution-sudans-attacks-on-peaceful-protesters-and-physicians/; https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/campaigns/2019/01/seven-things-you-should-know-about-the-unrest-in-sudan/ ; http://endgenocide.org/conflict-areas/sudan/

The ousting of Omar al-Basir from power due to numerous protests occurred early April and the sit in is still taking place. The military has taken control of the government and stated that they will return to civilian rule within two years but this proposal was rejected by the civilian protesters. The Sudanese army chief stated that they will not utilize force against civilians which is promising, but could just be an empty promise. 15 activists have been killed so far and their cause of death was by gunshot wound, which points the perpetrators to be the Sudanese regime. The Sudanese government is no stranger to killing civilians that oppose their rule, such as the egregious civilian casualties in the War in Dafur. There is a 40% chance of systematic killing campaign to occur due to the history of the Sudanese regime and the continued disagreements between the military government and the civilians protesting.
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-48021824
Assuming scope doesn't include South Sudan?
Renewed protests over Military Leadership - demanding return to civilian rule. THat transition took a week. Thinking the Military didn't make and/or KEEP many friends when they deposed the President.

Although the last coup in Sudanese history was thirty years ago, well within living memory for some people, the average age of Sudan is 18.9 years (https://www.statista.com/statistics/727308/average-age-of-the-population-in-sudan/). Such a young population that has grown up through the Darfur and South Sudan Conflicts, but are simultaneously more "connected" than their older peers, might be more inclined to demand for an end to violence and transition to civilian government. That said, the Sudanese military is no stranger to overthrowing democratically elected Sudanese governments and protecting its own interests. If the cost of cracking down based on protester actions is less than international scrutiny, using Bayes theorem I still give the chance of 1,000 or more civilian deaths of being around 35%. I hope in this case I don't have to revise my priors as this is something I'd rather not see happen.

If military goes through with invitation to the protest organisers and political parties to decide on a civilian prime minister and transition of power to citizens this might have a chance of not being bloody.
 But,I think, the military will, instead, make some cursory appointments designed to look like co-operation but really are substitutions of old guard with newer, more preferable supporters (judiciary, and defence posts).   Military is backed by Saudia Arabia, UAE and Egypt ... (Egypt wants control of Nile), and western allies with absolutely no desire to help civilian protesters achieve democracy...long drawn out bloodshed very likely.  Already civilian groups fighting with each other, but these won’t count for question

It is similar in nature to the uprising against Hosni Mobark with the concepts of "The Deep State" that is surely happen to exist in Sudan ruling regime , as military intrudes in the political order of the country sure thing that killing will take place to solve unresolved issues with the public.
The region is extremely unstable, oil rich and home to jihadist groups.
With the army appearing to back away from confrontation any major killing looks less and less likely
The murderous Janjaweed militias will retaliate for the overthrowal of their representative.
Sudan has become somewhat more politically unstable that it was in recent times

The military of Sudan is reacting to a popular uprising opposing the former dictator of Sudan. The military has effectively sided with the protesters and has ousted Omar al-Bashir. The military has made a "commitment" to hold free and fair elections as soon as possible after the end of a 3 month state of emergency constitutional suspension. The transition is stated to have a maximum timeline of 2 years. As long as order is maintained within Sudan wide spread violence is unlikely however because of the Military's zero policy rule of quelling protests, localized violence is probable.  One concern for the spread of violence is protest leader's acceptance of the 'temporary' military regime. Leaders of the SPA have already stated that the leaders of the coup are too similar to the former dictator and remain camped outside military headquarters in the capital vowing not to leave until an immediate transition to civilian rule before they leave. If the military can peacefully disperse this crowd of thousand and come to a compromise with civilian leaders the probability of systematic violence in the coming year will drop by ~10%.

Oh damn: I only saw the most recent developments now. lol. - President deposed. 2 year transition. 3 months state of emergency. [1]
- "Sudan’s state media reported that all political prisoners, including leaders of the protests, were in the process of being released from jails around the country. But protesters were angered that their demands for a civilian government were not met and vowed not to let the curfew end their massive sit-in in the capital, Khartoum." [2]  This uncertainty makes it significantly more likely I would guess. I update to 20%. [1] https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-47891470
[2] https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/sudans-military-expected-to-announce-overthrow-of-president-following-months-of-popular-protests/2019/04/11/bedcc28e-5c2b-11e9-842d-7d3ed7eb3957_story.html
The president of Sudan was just removed by the Sudanese military, so I believe there will be a crackdown of rule of law in the country in the near term

Base rate: between 1%-10% (best guess 2-3%). See here for more info: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/841007 Other judgments: 
- EWP estimate at 9.7%. [1]
- Crowd forecast here is 3%. Inside view: 
- EWP already count two such episodes: "We count two distinct ongoing state-led mass killings in Sudan: one in Darfur against non-Arab ethnic groups since 2003, and one in South Kordofan and Blue Nile against ethnic minorities since 2011." I assume the Janjaweed killings [2] are included in the Darfur campaign. In any case, the violence seems to have decreased over the past few years. Opposition forces also seem to have mainly attacked military targets. [3] A ceasefire is in place for the South Kordofan conflict and violence seems to have decreased. Again, opposition forces seem to have mainly attacked military targets. [4]
- there have been protests recently calling for the resignation of the presidents. About 20 protesters seem to have been killed over a few months. [5] [6] Overall judgment:
- the protests seem to be the most likely candidate for escalation, but not very likely overall. Other violence seems to have decreased significantly. However, the Sudanese government seems to be fairly open to such campaigns in general.
- my informed gut judgment is 5%. [1] https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/countries/sudan
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janjaweed
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_in_Darfur#2016
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudanese_conflict_in_South_Kordofan_and_Blue_Nile#2017
[5] https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-47858523
[6] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_Sudanese_protests
The political situation in Sudan is bordering chaotic. Although peaceful now, the army seems unpredictable.

Potential to get worse...but that doesn’t mean it will.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/apr/11/sudan-omar-al-bashir-protests-could-descend-chaos-anarchy-collapse-law-order-experts-warn
There is a national state of emergency in effect across Sudan...
As the economic gulf widens hatred will grow. We could be seeing another Rwanda.
